importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when New Delhi experienced one of its worst pollution episodes following Diwali celebrations, highlighting a recurring environmental crisis in the city.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period immediately following Diwali, when fireworks and firecrackers are traditionally used, exacerbates air pollution in New Delhi.

keyTakeAways: New Delhi recorded PM2.5 pollution levels more than 40 times higher than the World Health Organization's annual guideline level, marking one of the worst pollution spikes in the world.

The Diwali festival, known for fireworks and firecrackers, contributed significantly to the spike in air pollution, despite a 2020 ban on all firecrackers and a limited permit for 'green' firecrackers.
Enforcement of the green firecracker curfew was weak, with residents reporting that non-green firecrackers were still used well beyond the allowed time.
Residents expressed long-term health concerns, with many describing throat irritation and eye burning after exposure to polluted air.
Despite previous efforts like smog towers, traffic restrictions, and water sprinkling, systemic lack of enforcement and coordination has led to persistent air quality problems.
India’s economic growth and energy demands exacerbate environmental challenges, especially in major cities like New Delhi, Kolkata, and Mumbai, which are among the world’s most polluted cities.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Following Diwali celebrations, New Delhi experienced one of the most severe air pollution episodes in the world, with PM2.5 levels exceeding the World Health Organization’s safety guidelines by over 40 times. This spike is attributed to widespread use of traditional fireworks and firecrackers, despite a 2020 ban and a limited permit for 'green' firecrackers that were poorly enforced. Residents report serious health effects, including eye and throat irritation, while officials continue to struggle with long-term pollution control due to inadequate enforcement and systemic coordination. The crisis is part of a broader environmental issue in India, with other major cities like Kolkata and Mumbai also ranking among the world’s most polluted. This reflects a pressing need for stronger, consistently enforced environmental policies in urban centers to protect public health and address climate and air quality challenges.
title: After festival of lights, New Delhi plunged into toxic darkness and world’s most polluted air
